conclusion: The problem requires using the ideal gas law to relate pressure, volume, and temperature.
The ideal gas law equation is PV = nRT.
Variables in the ideal gas law: P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is gas constant, T is temperature.
Since the gas is ideal, the temperature T is constant for all states.
The ratio of the volumes VA/VB and VB/VC will be equal to the ratio of the pressures PA/PB and PB/PC.
Temperature at state A is 27Â°C, equivalent to 300 K.
Pressure at state A using ideal gas law: PA = nRT_A/VA.
Since TA = 300 K, PA = n * 300 * 10^5 / VA.
Since temperature at state B is the same as state A, PB = PA.
Pressure at state B using ideal gas law: PB = n * 300 * 10^5 / VB.
Since TB = 300 K, PB = n * 300 * 10^5 / VB.
Since temperature at state C is the same as state B, PC = PB.
Pressure at state C using ideal gas law: PC = n * 300 * 10^5 / VC.
Since TC = 300 K, PC = n * 300 * 10^5 / VC.
Solving for VC gives VC = VB.
Using ideal gas law for state C: PC = n * 300 * 10^5 / 6 * 10^-3.
